sen.e: As Emperor Juntoku stated that `shinji (a divine service) should take priority over everything else', in "Kinpisho" (a book written by Emperor Juntoku, which records the history and origin of imperial court ceremonies and sets forth the rules and etiquette for carrying out such ceremonies), emperors have been treating `shinji' as the highest priority since the birth of nation.

As Emperor Juntoku stated in the "Kinpisho" (a book written by Emperor Juntoku, which records the history and origin of the Imperial Court's ceremonies and sets forth the rules and etiquette for carrying out such ceremonies) that consideration should be given to divine service before other manners at the Imperial Court, successive emperors have given the highest priority to Shinto rituals since the establishment of the country.

sen.j: 宮中三殿で行われる祭祀には、天皇が自ら祭典を斎行し、御告文を奏上する大祭と、掌典長が祭典を行い、天皇が拝礼する小祭がある。
sen.e: Court rituals which are performed in the Three Shrines in the Imperial Court consist of taisai (grand festival); performed by the emperor himself and in which a message to imperial ancestors is announced, and shosai (small scale festival); performed by shotencho (the chief of shotenshoku, the section of the Imperial Household Agency handling the court ritual) and worshipped by the emperor.

Court rituals, which are performed in the Three Shrines of the Imperial Court, consist of taisai (grand festival), which is performed by the emperor himself and in which a message to imperial ancestors is announced, and shosai (small-scale festival), which is performed by shotencho (the chief of shotenshoku, the section of the Imperial Household Agency handling the court ritual) and worshiped by the emperor.

Court rituals which are performed in the Three Shrines in the Imperial Court consist of taisai (grand festivals), in which the Emperor himself conducts a ceremony and presents a message to the ancestors of the Imperial Family, and shosai (small festivals), in which the shoten-cho (the chief ritualist) conducts a ceremony and the Emperor bows his head in prayer.

sen.j: 現在行われている祭祀の多くは明治時代に大宝令、貞観儀式、延喜式などを継承して再編されたものである。
sen.e: Most of rituals that are still performed now were reorganized after succeeding Taiho-ryo (Taiho Code), Jogan gishiki (ceremony in the manner of Jogan period), and Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) in Meiji period.

Most of the rituals that are still performed were reorganized after the establishment of the Taiho-ryo (Taiho Code), Jogan gishiki (ceremony in the manner of Jogan period), and Engishiki (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) in the Meiji period.

Most of the present-day festivals are the rituals that were formalized based on the Taiho Code, the Jogan-gishiki (a set of books of ceremonial procedures compiled in the Jogan era), and the Engishiki (an ancient Japanese book of administrative regulations and ceremonial procedures that was completed in 927) in the Meiji period.

After the Meiji period, as the separation of Shinto and Buddhism and the deification of an emperor as 'Arahitogami' (a kami who appears in this world in human form), there occurred the renaissance of rituals and creation of additional rituals.

In the Meiji period, the revival of old festivals and the creation of new festivals were brought by the separation of Shinto and Buddhism and the deification of the Emperor that people regarded the Emperor as an 'arahitogami' (a living god).

sen.j: には「神社は国家の宗祀」との太政官布告が出され、には宮中祭祀について定めた皇室祭祀令が皇室令の一つとして制定された。
sen.e: The edict of Daijokan (The Grand Council of State); `Shrines and temples are enshrined by nation' was announced, and Koshitu Saishi Rei (Imperial household religious rites ordinance) which defines court rituals was established as a stipulation of Koshitsu-rei (the Imperial Families' Act).

In 1871, the Grand Council of State declared that Shinto shrines should be enshrined by the nation, and the Koshitsu Saishi Rei (the Ordinance of the Imperial Household Religious Rites), which defined Court rituals, was enacted as one of the Imperial Household Orders in 1908.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.e: In prewar Japan, Kunaisho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household), which governed the so-called 'kyuchu' (imperial court), had the authority almost equal to that of the cabinet, which governed 'Fuchu' (government).

Before World War II, the Ministry of Imperial Household administered the affairs of the Imperial Court, and its authority was almost equal to the authority of the Cabinet, which administered the government.

sen.e: Besides, from the legal aspect, the Constitution of the Empire of Japan which handled national administration and affairs and the laws and ordinances that were established under that equally coexist with the former Imperial House Act which handled the court affairs and various Koshitsu-rei (the Imperial Families' Act) established under that.

sen.e: Additionally, from the legal aspect the Constitution of the Empire of Japan, which handled the national administration and affairs as well as the laws and ordinances under it, which in turn equally coexisted with the former Imperial House Act, which handled the court affairs and various Koshitsu-rei (the Imperial Families' Act), were established.

Additionally, from the legal aspect of these institutes, the Constitution of the Empire of Japan, which handled the national administration and affairs, as well as various laws and ordinances established based on the Constitution equally coexisted with the former Imperial Household Law, which handled the Court affairs, and various Koshitsu-rei (the Imperial Household's Orders) under the Law.

sen.j: 昭和20年（1945年）8月に日本が敗戦すると、連合軍は宮内省を宮内府、宮内庁へと次々と降格させ、また皇室典範を日本国憲法下の一般法の一つとして位置づけなおした。
sen.e: When Japan defeated in the war in August, 1945, the allied forces demoted Kunaisho to Kunaifu (Imperial Household Agency) to Kunaichou (Imperial Household Agency) successively, and treated the former Imperial House Act as one of general law under the Constitution of Japan.

With Japan's defeat in the war in August 1945, the allied forces demoted Kunaisho to Kunaifu (Imperial Household Agency) to Kunaichou (Imperial Household Agency) successively, and treated the former Imperial House Act as one of general laws under the Constitution of Japan.

After Japan was defeated in World War II in August 1945, the Allies demoted the Ministry of Imperial Household to the Imperial Household Office, which was later demoted again to the Imperial Household Agency, and they ranked the Imperial Household Law as one of general laws, which should be under the control of the Constitution of Japan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: また、皇室典範の内容を全面的に「改正」すると共に、皇室祭祀令等戦前の皇室令を全て廃止した。
sen.e: Furthermore, they abolished all the Koshitsu-rei including Koshitu Saishi Rei that were established before the war as well as `amending' the content of Koshitu Saishi Rei thoroughly.
Furthermore, they abolished all the Koshitsu-rei, including Koshitu Saishi Rei, which were established before the war, and thoroughly 'amended' the content of Koshitu Saishi Rei.

Furthermore, they thoroughly 'amended' the contents of Imperial Household Law, and they also abolished all the Imperial Household Orders which were established before the war, including the Koshitsu Saishi Rei.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました

sen.j: 旧皇室令が廃止された際、宮内庁は内部通牒を出し、戦後明文の規定がなくなった事項についても旧皇室令に準じて実施することを確認している。
sen.e: Kunai chou ensured that the issues that were not stipulated after the war would be enforced in accordance with the former Koshitsu-rei by issuance of the internal document.
Kunai chou ensured that the issues that weren't stipulated after the war would be enforced in accordance with the former Koshitsu-rei, based on the issuance of the internal document.

When the former Imperial Household Orders were abolished, the Imperial Household Agency issued an internal notification in order to ensure that issues that lost explicit provisions after the war would be enforced according to the former Imperial Household Orders.

sen.e: However, the Constitution of Japan and the laws established under that have no expressive stipulation; the budget for the court rituals were also processed as of the daily living expenses of the Imperial Household.

The Constitution of Japan and laws established under the constitution, however, do not have any explicit provisions about the Court rituals, and the budget for the Court rituals is included in the budgeted allowance for the private expenses of the Imperial Family.

sen.e: Since attending the court rituals is a hard work for an emperor, simplifying and adjustments of rituals have been planned and implemented; on the purpose of reducing his hard work for Emperor Showa who was at old age from 1965 to 1985; in consideration of the present Emperor's health and reducing his work in 2009.

Because attendance at court rituals is hard work for an emperor, the simplification and adjustment of rituals have been planned and implemented for the purpose of reducing the hard work for Emperor Showa during his advanced years from 1965 to 1985, and in 2009, in consideration of the present Emperor's health and reducing the effort required.
